awd_titl_txt: EAGER:  Moving Beyond the Leaf Decay Analogy: Root Trait Controls on Decomposition and Soil Carbon Dynamics
awd_abstract_narration:
The decomposition of plant roots is not well understood. A significant amount of organic carbon (C) is bound up in roots, and the roots are the part of the plant that interacts with the soil, taking up nutrients and water.  Not all roots are the same - they come in a great variety of shapes and sizes, with different characteristics and chemistries.  This project will, for the first time, test new ideas about how dying roots are decomposed in soil, interact with soil minerals, and contribute to forest C cycling. An experimental system will be used to approximate what is taking place underground so that the mechanisms and rates of root decomposition can be better understood. The project will involve training opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students at Kent State University, as well as outreach activities for grade school students through Holden Arboretum in Kirtland, OH.  Researchers will also coordinate with established programs at Kent State University (Science Learning Community, Upward Bound, and Ohio Science & Engineering Alliance) to attract students from the greater Cleveland area, including those from under represented groups and first-generation college attendees, which make up 46% of the student body at Kent State.

Understanding how root traits affect soil C dynamics is key to accurate C modeling at local and global scales because roots provide the majority of C that is stabilized in soil. However, despite obvious differences in morphology, chemical composition and surrounding environment between roots and leaves, root decomposition is currently conceptualized and modeled almost entirely based on what is known about leaf decomposition. Fine root decomposition occurs at a fundamentally different spatial scale than leaf decomposition, resulting in closer interactions between the plant tissue, decomposer organisms, and mineral and molecular mechanisms involved in soil C stabilization. This proposal posits that root morphology is a key control over decomposition rates, and is the reason why plant species have different effects on soil organic matter pools.  Decomposition rate is expected to be affected by root morphology, as well as root chemical traits, because morphological traits control surface area as well as breaks in the epidermis available for microbial colonization. Moreover, root morphology likely has another, perhaps even larger, impact on the form of organic matter deposited in soil during root decomposition. It is predicted that plant species with thin and brittle first order roots are more likely to fragment, being deposited directly as particulate organic matter that can become further stabilized inside soil aggregates. By contrast, thick roots that are resistant to fragmentation during decomposition are predicted to sustain greater microbial activity, accompanied by production of dissolved organic C (DOC) and translocation of plant C to the surrounding soil.  These hypotheses will be tested using field and controlled laboratory microcosm experiments, by measuring mass loss rates of root systems representing a gradient of trait combinations and by taking advantage of differences in 13C signature between C3 and C4 plants to track root litter-derived C into different soil C pools. This study will test a new framework linking root traits to soil C dynamics in forests. The framework bridges an important gap between emerging information on 1) physical-mineralogical mechanisms by which C is stabilized in soil and 2) the distribution of tree root traits and their independence from leaf traits. Traits are particularly variable for woody arbuscular mycorrhizal plants, a dominant plant type in the tropics and many deciduous temperate forests. Biogeographical and phylogenetic patterns in root traits will facilitate their use in future modeling efforts, if a framework for soil C dynamics is developed that more broadly incorporates root traits.

NSF Award 1549964

Project Outcomes

Soils represent the largest terrestrial pool of carbon on Earth. Long-term carbon storage in soils occurs through stabilization of organic material derived from decomposing plant tissue. This stabilization of organic matter is due to interactions with clay mineral surfaces and protection by soil aggregates. Because plant roots are naturally embedded in the soil, interactions between organic matter and soil minerals begin immediately after root senescence. Thus, the majority of stored soil carbon is derived from root tissue in many ecosystems. Our project had two goals: to explore how root traits affect root decomposition and organic carbon stabilization, and to explore the drivers of root traits among plants.

Chemical composition of plant tissue is a well-recognized control over decomposition rates because it determines the rate and efficiency by which microorganisms can use the plant tissue. However, we hypothesized that morphological root traits would also be an important determinant of root decomposition and stabilization in soil due to the high surface area of roots and their intimate exposure to soil minerals. We conducted three decomposition experiments with roots in direct contact with mineral soil, maintaining important organic matter-mineral interactions and non-microbial, physical mechanisms of decomposition. We found that similar rates of decomposition can mask differences in mechanisms of decomposition and soil carbon sequestration during root litter decomposition, leading to differing short and long-term soil carbon dynamics. Changes in root characteristics showed that the primary mechanism of root decomposition can switch from microbial metabolic activity in thicker roots to physical fragmentation for the finest roots. Long, thin roots were particularly vulnerable to physical breakage and loss of fragments into the soil matrix, and so decomposed rapidly despite their chemical recalcitrance. Thicker roots with more favorable chemical composition were decomposed by microbial activity. These differing mechanisms of decomposition were also evident in the carbon deposited in the surrounding soil. Physically fragmented, thin roots contributed more particulate organic matter particles that can be protected by soil aggregates, with an intermediate carbon residence time. In contrast, the microbially decomposed, thick roots elevated soil microbial biomass, which contributes a smaller amount of carbon to soil overall but which may have a longer residence time due to interactions with clay mineral surfaces.

To relate the findings on root decomposition to plant distributions, we also compiled a global dataset of root and leaf trait information. Our objective here was to place various hypotheses about controls on fine root traits into a phylogenetic context in order to determine the extent to which broad phylogenetic relationships drive other patterns. All root traits examined were phylogenetically structured, although the strength of this phylogenetic structure varied dramatically among traits and plant growth forms. Root traits were correlated with leaf traits (nitrogen, specific leaf area, and vein density), growth form (e.g., woody and non-woody), mycorrhizal type (non-mycorrhizal, arbuscular mycorrhizal, and ectomycorrhizal), and climate variables, but these were largely confounded with phylogenetic effects. Phylogenetic reconstruction showed that significant shifts in diameter, specific root length and tissue density occurred as Angiosperms diversified during the Cretaceous, largely independently from leaf changes or mycorrhizal affiliation. Growth form was the only factor consistently associated with root traits, suggesting that diversification in root morphology during this period was associated with transitions from woody to non-woody habits.

Together, these projects suggest that an understanding of plant distributions can contribute to predictions of soil carbon storage mechanisms and stability. The plant evolutionary history of a biogeographic region may have cascading effects on root traits, and on patterns in soil carbon storage. This work may therefore be useful in future projections of plant migrations will affect soil carbon dynamics.

In addition to training opportunities provided to approximately a dozen students, this project has enabled activities bringing an interest in the natural world to the public through talks and activities. The personnel involved in this grant have been involved in helping design a large forest restoration project in Cuyahoga Valley National park, engaging with park staff and hundreds of volunteers. The project involves soil remediation treatment followed by tree plantings being conducted on large volunteer days. Volunteer crews are led by faculty and students involved in this project, resulting in short public talks and many educational scientific conversations with the public about trees, soils, roots, and effects of ecosystem dynamics on the broader environment.
